items: Skin infection due to community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staph. aureus (CA-MRSA).
Infection extends into the fascial plane between muscle and subcutaneous fat with resulting necrotizing fasciitis.

items: Empiric regimens should include gram-negative and anaerobic coverage in addition to the above, until pathogen identified. Then, switch to targeted therapy.
Historically, Staph. aureus was not associated with necrotizing fasciitis, but community-acquired MRSA is different and can cause the disease.
See Necrotizing Fasciitis, Overview for further discussion and links to other etiologies..
